Research Paper Unraveling the role of metal promoters (Zn, Cu, Co, Mn and Mg) in CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins over Fe-K catalysts Haonan Zu Writing – original draft Validation Methodology Data curation Conceptualization Huashuai Wu Writing – review & editing Validation Supervision ⁎ Jiarong Tian Investigation Ao Li Methodology Formal analysis Junwen Wang Supervision Project administration ⁎ College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Shanxi 030024, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology Shanxi 030024 China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Shanxi 030024, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Efficient CO2 utilization is crucial for mitigating environmental concerns. In this study, the promoting effect of transition metal (Zn, Cu, Co and Mn) and alkaline earth metal Mg on Fe-K catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins were investigated. A series of Fe-K catalysts with different metal modified were prepared using the activated carbon template method proposed in this work. This method greatly improves catalyst dispersion, enabling the synthesis of high-performance Fe-K catalysts. The promoter-dependent mechanisms governing catalyst performance and selectivity were revealed. Zn promotion significantly enhances Fe dispersion and electron transfer, resulting in electron-rich Fe5C2 and exceptional light olefin selectivity with a value of 35.00 %. Co maximizes CO2 conversion (46.88 %). However, Co promotes H2 dissociation, enhancing the formation of n-alkane products and reducing C2-C4 olefin-to-paraffin ratio. Adding Cu, while greatly enhancing the reduction and carburization behavior of iron oxides, significantly weakens the adsorption of CO2. The strong interaction between Mn and iron species leads to a complex reduction and carburization process of Fe-K catalyst and greatly reduces its basicity. The addition of Cu, Mg, and Mn greatly promote C-C coupling towards heavier hydrocarbons. These findings provide a comprehensive understanding of promoter roles and offer a rational strategy for designing advanced Fe-K catalysts for tailed CO2 hydrogenation product distributions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Light olefins Fe-based catalysts Metal promoters Activated carbon template 1 Introduction In response to the increasingly serious environmental problems, how to reduce CO2 emissions has attracted widespread attention [1–4]. Extensive research has been conducted, with a notable approach being the transformation of CO2 with green hydrogen into high-value-added light (C2-C4) olefins [5–7]. The production of light olefins by the hydrogenation of CO2 over Fe-based catalysts has been explored extensively [8]. It is widely recognized that the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction initially occurs over Fe-based catalysts to generate CO, followed by the hydrogenation of CO to hydrocarbons via the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction. Since Fe-based catalysts exhibit good catalytic activity for both the RWGS and the FTS reactions, they are expected to be the promising materials for the hydrogenation of CO2 to light olefins [9–11]. The unmodified Fe-based catalysts primarily produce methane, and the selectivity to olefins is relatively low. In order to improve the selectivity to olefins, alkali metal promoters like Li, Na, K, etc. are typically added into the Fe-based catalysts [12–15]. The addition of potassium (K) was employed as a promoter due to its ability to enhance the basicity of the catalyst, which is crucial for the adsorption of CO and CO2, while concurrently suppressing the adsorption of H2. This promotional effect is directly linked to the improved olefin selectivity by mitigating methane formation, as evidenced in previous studies [13,16,17]. Despite the recognized promoting effect of potassium on olefins selectivity, it is observed that Fe-based catalysts solely promoted by K often exhibit limitations in olefin selectivity and stability [18]. Consequently, current research focuses on the doping the catalysts with transition metals, including zinc (Zn), copper (Cu), manganese (Mn), cobalt (Co) and alkaline earth metal magnesium (Mg) to synergistically enhance their catalytic performance [18–23]. Among them, Zn is the most extensively studied promoter in Fe-based catalysts. The addition of Zn has been reported to result in the formation of ZnFe2O4. Compared to unmodified iron catalysts, the crystallite size of Fe-based catalysts containing ZnFe2O4 is smaller, which leads to the increase of the specific surface area. This suggests that the Zn can act as a structural promoter [24–26]. Zhang et al. also found that at a Zn/Fe ratio of 1:2, Zn migrated to the catalyst surface during the reaction, inhibiting the conversion of FeCx to FeOx [27]. This, in turn, suppressed the catalyst deactivation. Furthermore, they observed electron transfer from ZnO to Fe5C2 on the catalyst [28]. This electron transfer enhances the desorption of olefins, and inhibit the secondary hydrogenation of olefins, thereby increasing olefin selectivity. Moreover, the presence of Zn has been shown to enhance the adsorption of CO2 and facilitates the formation of iron carbide [29]. Gül et al. reported that adding Zn to Fe-based catalysts improved the catalyst stability [30]. This enhanced stability may be attributed to the formation of a microporous structure with a high surface area. The addition of Cu has been shown to improve catalyst reduction and carburization, promoting the formation of active phases [31]. While Cu has been reported to promote chain growth by enhancing the reduction and carburization of Fe-based catalysts [32,33], other studies suggest that it can inhibit the generation of long-chain hydrocarbons. Moreover, the presence of Cu also enhances the activation of H2, increasing the hydrogenation capability of the catalysts. This results in a significant decrease in the olefin-to-paraffin ratio. Zhao et al. [34] found that Cu can alter the electronic structure of the catalyst and the increase of Cu content changed the Fe2+/Fe3+ ratio on the catalyst surface and increased the oxygen vacancies. Adding Mn could enhance the selectivity towards long-chain hydrocarbons. However, the strong interactions between Fe and Mn can inhibit catalyst carburization [30,31]. Co is known to exhibit high FTS activity. Adding a small amount of Co to Fe-based catalysts has been shown to improve reaction activity and olefin generation, while also enhancing resistance to catalyst sintering [35]. However, some studies indicate that Co promotes CH4 generation [15]. MgO is another promoter that has shown promise in Fe-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation [36–38]. Studies by Sheraz Ahmed et al. [36,37] have demonstrated that MgO can enhance the reducibility of Fe3O4 and is conducive to the formation of oxygen vacancies. However, MgO can also transform to MgCO3 during the reaction process, which leads to catalyst deactivation. The content of MgO has a significant effect on the olefin-to-paraffin ratio in the long-chain hydrocarbons. Despite extensive research, the complexity of Fe-based catalysts makes it challenging to understand the role of transition and alkaline earth metal promoters and their effects remain controversial. Moreover, a comprehensive theoretical understanding of how these promoters influence light olefin selectivity is still lacking. This lack of understanding hinders the rational design of improved Fe-based catalysts for light olefins. In this study, a series of Fe-K catalysts with various metals (Zn, Cu, Co, Mn and Mg) modified were prepared by using a two-step synthesis method proposed in this work. By combining various characterization techniques, the promoting effects of each metal promoter has on the Fe-K catalyst were elucidated. 2 Experimental method 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Fe-based catalysts doped with different metal additives were prepared via the activated carbon template method. Activated carbon serves as a template during catalyst synthesis. Its primary function is to facilitate the uniform dispersion of the metal precursors throughout the catalyst material prior to calcination. The detailed catalyst preparation procedure is as follows. A 5 ml solution containing Fe(NO3)3·9H2O and M(NO3) x ·xH2O (M=Zn, Cu, Co, Mn and Mg) was gradually added dropwise to 2.5 g of pretreated activated carbon (pre-heated and stirred in a 90 °C water bath until neutral pH was achieved) under constant stirring. Subsequently, the obtained mixture was ultrasonicated for 40 min and then impregnated for 24 h. Thereafter, the impregnated sample was dried in an oven at 120 °C for 4 h and calcined in a muffle furnace at 550 °C for 5 h. Finally, the calcined samples were added into anhydrous ethanol and subjected to ultrasonic centrifugation to remove impurities followed by drying. The prepared catalysts were denoted as Fe-M (M=Zn, Cu, Co, Mn, and Mg; Fe/M ratio of 2:1). The pure Fe catalyst was prepared using the same method as above, with only Fe(NO3)3·9H2O added. The K species were loaded via the incipient wetness impregnation method. KNO3 was gradually added to the previously prepared catalyst under constant stirring. Subsequently, the obtained mixture was ultrasonicated for 40 min and then impregnated for 24 h. Finally, the impregnated sample was dried in an oven at 120 °C and calcined in a muffle furnace at 350 °C for 5 h. The prepared K-promoted catalysts with a K loading of 2 % were denoted as Fe-M-K (M=Zn, Cu, Co, Mn, and Mg). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The phase composition of the catalysts was characterized by XRD using a Shimadzu-6000 X-ray diffractometer. The scanning range was from 20° to 80°, using Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.154 nm), a tube voltage of 40 kV, a tube current of 40 mA, and a step size of 0.02°/s. The specific surface areas of the catalysts were determined using a Micrometrics ASPA 2000 instrument via N2 physical adsorption. The catalyst was placed in a quartz glass tube and pretreated under vacuum at 120 °C for 2 h, and then subjected to N2 adsorption/desorption analysis at −196 °C. The chemical compositions of the catalysts were analyzed using Inductively Coupled Plasma-Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on an Agilent 5110 ICPOES. The micromorphology of the catalysts was analyzed using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL-JSM-7500F). The Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS) maps were conducted using the same equipment employed for SEM characterization. The microstructure and crystallite size of the catalysts were characterized using a JEM-F200 transmission electron microscope (TEM). H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on the TP-5076 dynamic adsorption instrument. The sample was pretreated at 300 °C in a N2 atmosphere for 1 hour, then cooled down to room temperature in the same atmosphere. Subsequently, a gas mixture of 10 % H2/N2 was introduced and the temperature was ramped up to 850 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1, while recording the data. CO temperature-programmed reduction (CO-TPR) was performed on the same apparatus, with the exception that the gas mixture used was 10 % CO/N2. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) measurements were performed on a TP-5076 dynamic adsorption instrument. The post-reaction catalyst was pretreated at 350 °C in a pure He atmosphere for 2 h, then cooled down to room temperature in the same atmosphere. Subsequently, high-purity CO2 was introduced and adsorbed onto the catalyst surface. After adsorption, the system was purged with a He atmosphere, and the temperature was ramped up to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 with data recording during the process. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were acquired on a Thermo Fischer Scientific Nexsa instrument, and the spectra were charge calibrated according to the standard of C 1 s at 284.8 eV. 2.3 Catalytic performance evaluation CO2 hydrogenation to olefins were performed in a high pressure fixed bed reactor. Typically, 0.5 g catalyst mixed with 1 g quartz sand (both in 20–40 mesh) was packed in the isothermal section of the fixed bed reactor furnace. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was pre-reduced for 8 h at a flow rate of 50 ml min-1 at 400 °C in a pure H2 atmosphere. After cooling down to 100 °C, a reactant gas mixture with an H2/CO2 molar ratio of 3:1 was introduced into the reactor. The reaction was carried out at 320 °C, 2 MPa and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 8000 ml gcat -1 h-1. The gaseous effluent from the reactor were analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC, GC-920). Typically, H2, N2, CO, CH4, and CO2 were analyzed using TCD, which is connected with a 5A molecular sieve packed column. Hydrocarbons were detected using FID, which is connected with a carbon molecular sieve packed column and a modified alumina packed column. Under the same chromatographic conditions, the certified standard gas corresponding to the sample was analyzed separately to determine the correction factors. The concentrations of product components were calculated through normalization processing and the detection data were correlated according to CH4 content. CO2 conversion was calculated according to Eq. (1): (1) X C O 2 = F C O 2 , in − F C O 2 , out F C O 2 , in × 100 % CO selectivity was obtained based on Eq. (2): (2) S CO = F CO , out F C O 2 , in − F C O 2 , out × 100 % Hydrocarbon distribution was calculated from Eq. (3): (3) S i = i F i , out F C O 2 , in − F C O 2 , out − F CO , out × 100 % where, F C O 2 , in and F C O 2 , out (mol h-1) are the molar flow rates of CO2 at the inlet and outlet of the reactor, respectively; F CO , out (mol h-1) is the molar flow rate of CO at the outlet of the reactor; F i , out (mol h-1) is the molar flow rate of olefins or n-alkane products with a carbon number of i at the outlet of the reactor. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the Fe-based catalysts A series of Fe-based catalysts were prepared using a two-step synthesis method proposed in this work. Specifically, five catalysts (Fe-Zn-K, Fe-Cu-K, Fe-Co-K, Fe-Mn-K, and Fe-Mg-K) were synthesized with a Fe-K catalyst prepared for performance comparison. 3.1.1 Textural property, structure and morphology To quantitatively determine the elemental composition of the catalysts, and in particular, to verify the consistency of iron content in all catalysts, ICP-OES analysis was performed. The results of the ICP-OES analysis are summarized in Table S1 (Supporting Information). As presented in Table S1, the measured iron content in all metal-promoted Fe-K catalysts remained remarkably consistent, exhibiting only minor variations. XRD patterns of the fresh catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . The absence of characteristic diffraction peaks associated with K species confirms that the K species was well distributed in all the catalysts. All the catalysts exhibited peaks at 2θ=24.14°, 33.15°, 35.61°, 40.85°, 49.48°, 54.09°, 62.45°, and 63.99°, corresponding to the characteristic diffraction peaks of α-Fe2O3 (PDF#33–0664). With the exception of Fe-Mn-K, a weak spinel diffraction peak was observed at approximately 2θ=30° for all the other catalysts. This suggests the presence of spinel phases. In contrast, no spinel diffraction peaks were observed in the Fe-Mn-K catalyst, possibly due to solid solution formation. The diffraction peaks corresponding to CuO (PDF#80–1917) and Mn2O3 (PDF#89–4836) were observed for Fe-Cu-K and Fe-Mn-K catalysts, respectively. The absence of diffraction peaks associated with Mg and Co indicate that they were highly dispersed in the α-Fe2O3 bulk phase. Changes in the peak intensity and full width at half maximum (FWHM) were observed after doping with transition and alkaline earth metals, indicating that these transition and alkaline earth metals were successfully incorporated into the iron catalysts. It is noticed that the diffraction peak near 2θ=35.61° becomes more prominent for Fe-Zn-K, Fe-Cu-K and Fe-Co-K catalysts, compared to Fe-K, where the peak at 2θ=33.15° is dominant. For Fe-Cu-K, the increased intensity at 35.61° is potentially due to interference from CuO diffraction peaks, as CuO exhibits characteristic peaks in this 2θ range. For Fe-Zn-K and Fe-Co-K, however, the enhanced 35.61° peak is more likely a result of structural modification within the α-Fe2O3 phase. The incorporation of Zn and Co promoters during calcination can induce preferential growth of certain Fe2O3 crystallographic planes, leading to altered diffraction intensities. Additionally, the possibility of spinel structure formation in Fe-Zn-K and Fe-Co-K could also contribute to these XRD pattern changes. As indicated in Table S2, compared to Fe-K, the incorporation of the above metal promoters resulted in an increase in the BET specific surface area and a decrease in the pore diameter of the catalysts. The introduction of Zn and Mg greatly increased the BET specific surface areas as well as decreased the pore diameters while the influence of other transition metals was not that significant. Especially, Cu and Mn exhibited the smallest increase in specific surface area and decrease in pore diameters, which may be due to the formation of corresponding metal oxides, as confirmed by the XRD results. The observed increase in the BET specific surface area and decrease in the pore size of the iron catalysts is beneficial for the dispersion and exposure of active sites, thereby enhancing the catalytic performance. The morphologies of fresh catalysts were characterized using SEM, and the representative images are illustrated in Fig. 2 . The Fe-K and Fe-Cu-K catalysts were found to exhibit aggregated granular structures with a closed packed arrangement (see Fig. 2(a), (c)). Notably, the introduction of Cu promoter did not induce a discernible change in the morphology compared to the Fe-K catalyst. This compact granular morphology observed in Fe-K and Fe-Cu-K catalysts is consistent with their relatively low BET specific surface areas, as detailed Table S2 in the Supporting Information. It can be further inferred that this structure may not be favorable for improving the surface area of the iron catalyst. The incorporation of Co and Mn promoters resulted in a morphological transformation towards smaller and more loosely distributed granular structures (Fig. 2(d), (e)). These catalysts displayed a less densely packed surface compared to the Fe-K and Fe-Cu-K catalysts. Furthermore, the catalysts promoted by Zn and Mg displayed a unique needle-like morphology, with these needle-shaped particles being loosely dispersed on the catalyst surface (Fig. 2(b), (f)). This distinctive needle-like morphology observed for Zn- and Mg-promoted catalysts may contribute to their enhanced BET specific surface areas and reduced pore size, as reported in Table S2. Based on the above results, it is inferred that the addition of transition and alkaline earth metals, significantly influences the morphology of the iron-based catalysts. In particular, Zn promoter appears to promote the formation of a needle-like structure, potentially leading to improved dispersion of Fe species. Based on the superior dispersion observed for the Zn-promoted catalyst, TEM was further employed to characterize the microstructure of the Fe-K and Fe-Zn-K catalysts (Fig. 3 ). TEM analysis of the fresh Fe-K catalyst revealed an aggregated granular morphology with an average particle size of 45.02 nm. The Fe-Zn-K catalyst exhibited a distinct needle-like morphology with a more dispersed distribution of particles on the catalyst surface. The TEM analysis confirmed a smaller average particle size of 28.14 nm for Fe-Zn-K. This reduced particle size in Fe-Zn-K is potentially associated with the formation of the spinel ZnFe2O4 phase, as supported by the XRD results. These TEM observation were in good agreement with the morphological features identified by SEM and the phase composition determined by XRD. 3.1.2 Reduction and carburization behavior To elucidate the reduction behavior of the catalysts, H2-TPR was performed, and the profiles are presented in Fig. 4 (a). The Fe-K catalyst exhibited a profile with three distinct H2 consumption peaks, indicative of the stepwise reduction of α-Fe2O3. The low-temperature peak (300–500 °C) corresponds to the reduction of α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, while the peaks in the high-temperature range (500–800 °C) are attributed to the sequential reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO and subsequently FeO to α-Fe [39,40]. Three reduction peaks were observed for the H2-TPR profile of the Fe-Zn-K catalyst, indicating a reduction pathway of α-Fe2O3 → Fe3O4 → FeO → α-Fe. A notable shift towards lower temperatures is observed for Fe-Zn-K compared to Fe-K, suggesting that the addition of Zn enhances the reducibility of the iron catalyst. Similar reduction peak profiles and temperature shifts are observed for the Fe-Mg-K catalyst, which implies that Mg and Zn exert comparable promoting effects on catalyst reducibility. In contrast, the Fe-Cu-K catalyst exhibited a H2-TPR profile with only two discernible reduction peaks. The first peak, occurring at a significantly lower temperature, is attributed to the concurrent reduction of CuO to Cu and α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. The second reduction peak corresponded to the final reduction of Fe3O4 to α-Fe. The reduced number of peaks and the significant decrease in onset temperatures for both peaks clearly demonstrate that Cu dramatically enhances the reducibility of the catalyst and simplifies the overall reduction process. While the Fe-Co-K catalyst also exhibited three reduction peaks, the temperature ranges for the second and third peaks were notably narrower compared to Fe-K. This peak narrowing suggests a more continuous and efficient reduction process from Fe3O4 to FeO and then to α-Fe. Furthermore, the reduction onset temperature of the Fe-Co-K catalyst is significantly lower than that of Fe-Cu-K, demonstrating that Co exhibits a more pronounced promoting effect on reducibility than Cu. This enhanced reducibility by Cu and Co can be attributed to their ability to facilitate H2 dissociation, generating active hydrogen species that is beneficial for the reduction of iron oxide [41,42]. The Fe-Mn-K catalyst, while exhibiting a decreased reduction onset temperature, displays a more complex H2-TPR profile with multiple overlapping peaks. This peak multiplicity suggests the presence of multiple reduction processes, potentially arising from the formation of a Fe-Mn solid solution, which complicates the reduction pathway [43]. CO-TPR were performed to investigate the carburization behavior of the catalysts and the resulting profiles are shown in Fig. 4(b). The Fe-K catalyst exhibited two distinct CO reduction peaks. The first peak corresponds to the reduction of α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, while the second, significantly larger peak is attributed to the subsequent carburization of Fe3O4 to form Fe5C2. The larger area of the second peak suggests the simultaneous occurrence of multiple processes during this stage, including carbide transformation and the Boudouard reaction [44]. Consistent with H2-TPR results, the Fe-Cu-K catalyst exhibited a CO-TPR profile shifted to lower reduction temperatures, indicating enhanced low-temperature reducibility and carburization, likely due to the presence of readily reducible CuO. The Fe-Co-K catalyst displayed a significantly larger area for the first consumption peak compared to Fe-K, suggesting that Co promotes the initial reduction of α-Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. Moreover, the temperature ranges for both CO consumption peaks are narrower for Fe-Co-K, indicating that Co facilitates a more uniform and complete reduction and carburization process, consistent with the XRD results. In summary, Cu primarily enhances low-temperature reducibility, while Co promotes a more complete and homogeneous reduction and carburization. Similar to the H2-TPR results, the CO-TPR profiles of Fe-Zn-K and Fe-Mg-K catalysts exhibited similar peak distributions. Two reduction peaks were observed, corresponding to the sequential reduction of α-Fe2O3→Fe3O4 and subsequent carburization to Fe5C2. The reduction onset temperatures for Fe-Zn-K and Fe-Mg-K are lower than that of Fe-K, suggesting that Zn and Mg promote catalyst reduction and carburization. However, their promotional effect is less pronounced compared to Cu and Co. The Fe-Mn-K catalyst showed a substantially increased peak area in the first stage compared to Fe-K, indicating that Mn incorporation facilitates the initial reduction step. Furthermore, the peak areas of the second CO reduction for all the transition and alkaline earth metal decorated catalysts were found to be smaller than that of Fe-K. This observation suggests that the addition of these promoters may suppress undesirable side reactions during CO reduction, potentially reducing carbon deposition and favoring the formation of active phase Fe5C2, which is beneficial for the generation of olefins. 3.1.3 Surface component To investigate the surface chemical states of iron and the influence of promoters, XPS analysis was performed on the fresh catalysts and the results are shown in Fig. 5 . In this study, our primary focus is on understanding the role of metal promoters in modulating the catalytic performance of Fe-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. As iron is the primary active sites for CO2 hydrogenation in our Fe-based catalysts, understanding its electronic state and chemical environment is crucial for elucidating the catalytic mechanism and the impact of promoters. Therefore, we performed a detailed analysis of the Fe 2p spectra to gain the most relevant insights into the active phase. For the Fe-K catalyst, a Fe 2p3/2 peak at the binding energy of 710.74 eV with a satellite peak at approximately 718.4 eV was observed. This is assigned to the standard α-Fe2O3 phase [38,45]. The incorporation of transition metals (Zn, Cu, Co and Mn) and alkaline earth metal Mg led to a slight shift in the Fe 2p peaks towards higher binding energies. Specifically, the binding energy values of Fe 2p3/2 were determined to be 710.85 eV for Fe-Zn-K, 710.89 eV for Fe-Cu-K, 710.82 eV for Fe-Co-K, 710.79 eV for Fe-Mn-K, and 710.76 eV for Fe-Mg-K. This increase in the Fe 2p binding energies upon promoter addition indicates a modification of the electronic environment of the iron species. The observed changes in the Fe surface chemical state, therefore, are likely associated with the structural modifications induced by the promoters, such as the formation of spinel phases, and may contribute to catalytic performance. The surface element content of the catalysts is presented in Table 1 . Compared to Fe-K, Cu- and Mn-modified catalysts exhibited an enrichment of K, whereas Zn-, Mg-, and Co-modified catalysts showed a reduction in K content. 3.2 Characterization of the spent catalysts 3.2.1 Phase compositions The XRD patterns for the 40 h spent catalysts were collected to investigate the effect of each metal promoter has on the structural evolution of catalysts during CO2 hydrogenation. As shown in Fig. 6 , the diffraction peaks assigned to Fe5C2 (at 2θ=37.06°, 39.37°, 40.85°, 43.47°, 44.17°) (PDF#89–7272) were identified for all of the catalysts, consistent with that Fe5C2 is widely recognized as the primary active phase for iron-based catalysts. The Fe-K catalyst exhibited diffraction peaks at 2θ=30.12°, 35.48°, 37.12°, 47.22°, 53.50°, 57.03°, and 62.63°, which is assigned to Fe3O4 (PDF#75–0033). Fe-K catalysts with the above metal promoters modified showed weak diffraction peaks for Fe3O4, which may be due to the uniform dispersion of Fe3O4 or the promotion of carburization. Zn-, Mg-, and Mn-modified catalysts exhibited corresponding metal carbonates after the reaction. This may be due to the reaction between CO2 and the corresponding metal oxides. The formation of FeCO3 in the Zn-promoted catalyst can be explained by the enhanced interaction between CO2 and Fe species under reaction conditions. As reported in the literature [31,46], Zn and Mg facilitate the adsorption and activation of CO2 on the catalyst surface. This enhanced CO2 adsorption and activation promotes the formation of carbonate-like intermediates, such as FeCO3. It is important to clarify that FeCO3 is not considered as the active phase for CO2 hydrogenation. Instead, its presence indicates that CO2 is effectively activated on the catalyst surface, which is a crucial step for the hydrogenation reaction. However, the formation of FeCO3 may potentially reduce the concentration of active iron sites available for hydrogenation, which could negatively impact the overall catalytic performance. Sharp metallic Cu (PDF#89–2838) diffraction peaks were found for Fe-Cu-K catalyst, indicating that CuO was reduced during the reaction. For Fe-Co-K, only Fe5C2 phase was observed, which may be due to the strong interaction between Co and Fe, enhancing the carburization process, thereby promoting the formation of Fe5C2. To quantify the relative amounts of different crystalline phases, quantitative analysis of the post-reaction XRD patterns was performed. The results of this analysis are presented in Table S3 in the Supporting Information. As detailed in Table S3, the quantitative XRD analysis reveals that catalysts modified with metal promoters exhibited a demonstrably higher content of iron carbides. This observation indicates that the introduction of metal promoter enhances the reduction and carburization of the catalysts under the reaction conditions, therefore providing a plausible explanation for their improved catalytic performance in light olefin production. SEM was employed to assess the morphological changes of the catalysts after reaction (Fig. S1). The Fe-K catalyst exhibited significant morphological alteration after reaction, characterized by the formation of large agglomerates. This observation sintering of the iron species during the reaction process. Compared to Fe-K, catalysts promoted with transition metals (Zn, Cu, Co and Mn) and alkaline earth metal Mg exhibited a markedly improved dispersion and a less aggregated state. Notably, the formation of large agglomerates was significantly reduced or even absent in these promoted catalysts. Among them, the Zn-promoted catalyst demonstrated the most homogeneous dispersion, indicating its superior resistance to catalyst sintering under reaction conditions. To further investigate the elemental distribution and the influence of promoters on active phase dispersion after reaction, EDS mapping was performed (Fig. 7 ). The EDS mapping results revealed that the introduction of metal promoters led to a more dispersed distribution of the iron across the catalyst surface in all promoted samples compared to Fe-K. In the Fe-Zn-K catalyst, the EDS mapping indicated a close spatial correlation between Fe and K suggesting a strong interaction between these elements, with K being located within the Fe-rich region. This improved dispersion and sintering resistance, likely contributes to the stabilization of the active phase and the enhanced catalytic performance observed in Fe-Zn-K. For Mn- and Mg-promoted catalysts, EDS mapping suggested a degree of phase separation between Mn and Fe, and Mg and Fe, respectively. This phase separation is potentially attributable to the formation of corresponding metal carbonates under reaction conditions, which is consistent with the post-reaction XRD results. 3.2.2 Surface chemistry The adsorption of CO2 on the catalyst, followed by C-C coupling, is a crucial step in the catalytic hydrogenation reaction mechanism. To evaluate surface basicity of the spent catalysts and their CO2 adsorption characteristics, CO2-TPD experiments were thus conducted. The corresponding CO2-TPD profiles are presented in Fig. 8 . The profile of Fe-K catalyst was found to exhibit two distinct desorption peaks, which are assigned to the desorption of CO2 at medium-strength and strongly basic sites, respectively. The total amount of CO2 adsorbed on the Fe-K catalyst was quantified as 87 μmol/g. Upon the introduction of metal promoters, a general trend of desorption peaks shifts towards lower temperatures was observed for both medium-strength and strongly basic sites. This shift suggests that the incorporation of metal promoters generally reduces the adsorption strength of CO2 on the catalyst surface. The addition of Cu promoter showed a negligible effect on the formation of medium-strength sites. However, it resulted in a decrease in the amount of CO2 adsorption at the strongly basic sites, reducing the total CO2 adsorption to 53 μmol/g. This reduction may be attributed to the potential blockage of basic sites by the incorporated Cu species. The Fe-Zn-K and Fe-Mg-K catalysts exhibited an increase in the total amount of CO2 adsorption, particularly at medium-strength basic sites, reaching 122 μmol/g and 105 μmol/g, respectively. This enhancement in CO2 adsorption capacity may be correlated with their increased BET specific surface areas (Table S2), which potentially leads to a greater exposure of basic sites. For the Co- and Mn-promoted catalysts, the CO2 adsorption peaks displayed a significant shift towards lower temperatures, indicating a marked reduction in the surface basicity strength. The Fe-Co-K catalyst exhibited the lowest CO2 adsorption amount among all catalysts, at 30 μmol/g, suggesting that Co significantly diminishes the number of basicity sites. While the total CO2 adsorption amount for the Fe-Mn-K catalyst remained relatively constant compared to Fe-K (78 μmol/g vs. 87 μmol/g), the pronounced shift of desorption peaks to lower temperatures confirms a substantial decrease in the basicity strength upon Mn promotion. To investigate the chemical state of iron species on the catalyst surface after reaction, XPS was performed (Fig. 9 ). The Fe 2p spectra were analyzed and deconvoluted into six distinct peaks. Specifically, the peaks observed at binding energies of approximately 710 eV and 723 eV are assigned to Fe2+ species, indicative of iron in a lower oxidation state. Peaks at approximately 712 eV and 726 eV are attributed to Fe3+ species, corresponding to iron in a higher oxidation state. Additionally, a peak at approximately 714 eV and 719 eV, is assigned to a satellite feature and iron carbide (Fe5C2), respectively [47–50]. In all metal-modified Fe-K catalyst, with the exception of Fe-Cu-K, the binding energy of the Fe5C2 peak shifted towards lower values. This suggests an increased electron density around the iron species in the carbide phase. It indicates that the incorporation of these metal additives enhances electron transfer to iron species, resulting in the formation of more electron-rich iron carbide. Conversely, the Fe-Cu-K catalyst exhibited an increase in binding energy of the Fe5C2 peak. This behavior in the Cu-modified catalyst could potentially be attributed to the formation of metallic copper (Cu0) during the reaction. The presence of metallic Cu, with its lower electronegativity compared to iron, may induce electron transfer from the iron species, leading to a decrease in electron density and a consequent shift of the Fe5C2 peak to higher binding energies. The detection of both Fe2+ and Fe5C2 peaks in the XPS spectra provides direct evidence that the catalysts underwent a reduction and carburization process during the reaction, resulting in the coexistence of iron oxide and iron carbide phases on the catalyst surface. The surface element content of spent catalysts is presented in Table 2 . After the incorporation of transition (Zn, Cu, Co and Mn) or alkaline earth metal Mg, the Fe3+ content was observed to be lower than that of Fe2+, indicating that adding the second promoter was conducive to catalyst reduction. This is also consistent with the H2-TPR results. The Fe5C2 content in the Fe-Co-K catalyst was the highest, indicating that the surface was enriched with Fe5C2. This finding is consistent with the XRD results of the spent catalysts. After reaction, Zn- and Co-modified Fe-K catalysts also displayed a Fe5C2 peak at about 706.8 eV and 707.0 eV. The binding energy of Fe5C2 in the Fe-Zn-K catalyst was lower than that in the Fe-Co-K catalyst, indicating that the electron density of Fe5C2 in the Fe-Zn-K catalyst was higher. The decrease in binding energy of iron carbide indicates the formation of electron-rich Fe5C2. This is beneficial for strengthening Fe-C bond and weakening C-O bond, consequently improving the catalytic performance [50]. 3.3 Catalytic performance of the Fe-based catalysts The influence of various metals (Zn, Cu, Co, Mn and Mg) on the catalytic performance of Fe-K catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins are presented in Fig. 10 (a). For the Fe-K catalyst, CO2 conversion reached a value of 43.35 % with a CO selectivity of 12.06 %. Compared to the unmodified Fe-K catalyst, the Mg- and Co-modified catalysts exhibited an enhanced catalytic activity for CO2 conversion. The enhanced CO2 conversion over the Fe-Mg-K catalyst may be due to its enhanced BET specific surface area, which leads to exposing more active sites. Particularly, the Co-modified catalyst achieved the highest CO2 conversion with the lowest selectivity to CO, which could be due to the promotion of the FTS reaction by Co [51]. The addition of Co might greatly enhance the FTS reaction rate, which leads to an enhanced consumption of CO. This could further shift the equilibrium of RWGS reaction so that RWGS reaction proceeds in the forward direction, which leads to an enhanced transformation of CO2 and CO. It was observed that Zn-, Cu- and Mn-modified catalysts experience a slight decrease in CO2 conversion, which may be due to the decrease in the basicity of catalysts with the addition of Zn, Cu and Mn. Obviously, Fe-Mn-K catalyst achieved the highest selectivity to CO. This may be attributed to the suppression of FTS reaction rate by the addition of Mn, which is unfavorable for the consumption of CO, thus increasing the selectivity to CO. From data illustrated in Fig. 10(a), Fe-K catalyst displayed a modest selectivity towards light olefins (C2 =-C4 =) with a value of 23.77 %. This can be attributed to the formation of Fe5C2 phase, which can be confirmed by XRD results. Compared to Fe-K catalyst, all of metal-modified Fe-K catalysts displayed an enhanced selectivity to light olefins. This enhancement may be due to that the interaction between the transition or alkaline earth metals and iron species has promoted the dispersion of catalysts, as confirmed by SEM results. This high dispersion of catalysts is beneficial for the stabilization of the Fe5C2 phase, thereby helping to prevent catalyst sintering during the reaction. The selectivity to light olefin for the Zn and Co-modified Fe-K catalysts was much higher than that of the other catalysts, which may be due to their high content of electron-rich Fe5C2, as observed from XPS data. In comparison to Fe-Co-K catalyst, Fe-Zn-K catalyst demonstrated a higher selectivity toward light olefins. This is possibly due to its higher electron density around Fe species, as also confirmed by XPS results. Furthermore, the introduction of all the investigated metals, with the exception of Co, increased CH4 selectivity. It is suggested that Co is conductive to the generation of CH4 in CO2 hydrogenation reactions[15]. The addition of the above metal promoters except Co also significantly inhibited the hydrogenation activity of the Fe-K catalyst, leading to an increase in the C2-C4 olefin-to-paraffin ratio. Compared to other transition and alkaline earth metals, the addition of Co is favorable for the formation of both alkanes and olefins, thereby increasing the selectivity towards alkanes and markedly decreases the C2-C4 olefin to paraffin ratio. Cu-, Mg-, and Mn-modified catalysts exhibited the lowest selectivity to CH4 and the highest selectivity to C5 + products. It is inferred that adding Cu-, Mg- and Mn-modified could significantly inhibit the generation of CH4 and light n-alkanes, while promote the generation of long-chain hydrocarbons. This may be due to the fact that Cu, Mg, or Mn could promote C-C coupling as well as inhibit further hydrogenation of light olefins during the reaction. While XPS analysis (Table 2) indicated low Fe-C content on the surface of Fe-Mn-K and Fe-Mg-K catalysts, these catalysts surprisingly exhibited high selectivity towards C5 + (57.56 % and 57.09 %, respectively). The observed discrepancy can be attributed to the fact that XPS analysis is primarily sensitive to the elemental composition and chemical states of the catalyst surface. In contrast, quantitative XRD analysis (Table S3), which provides information on the bulk crystalline phases, confirmed that presence of substantial Fe5C2 formation within the bulk structure of both Fe-Mn-K and Fe-Mg-K catalysts. Thus, XPS and XRD provide complementary information about the catalyst structure. The low Fe-C content detected by XPS for Fe-Mn-K and Fe-Mg-K catalysts does not contradict the XRD findings or their high C5 + selectivity. Besides, the downshift of the Fe-C binding energy observed in XPS for Fe-Mn-K and Fe-Mg-K, compared to Fe-K, suggests the formation of electron-enriched iron carbide at the catalyst surface. This surface electron enrichment, even with limited surface Fe-C content detected by XPS, can still enhance CO adsorption and dissociation, promoting C-C coupling and chain growth, ultimately contributing to the high C5 + selectivity [52]. The long-term stability of the catalysts was evaluated under continuous reaction conditions for 84 h. The time-on-stream performance, as depicted in Fig. 10(b) reveals distinct stability profiles for different catalysts. The Fe-Zn-K catalyst demonstrated remarkable stability throughout the 84-hour test period. As illustrated in Fig. 10(b), CO2 conversion remained consistently high, averaging 37.6 % with minimal fluctuation over time. This exceptional stability can be attributed to the enhanced anti-sintering properties imparted by the Zn promoter. The presence of Zn effectively mitigates the agglomeration of iron species during the reaction, thereby stabilizing the active phase and maintain consistent catalytic performance. This observation is in strong agreement with the post reaction SEM analysis, which demonstrated superior dispersion for the Zn-promoted catalyst. The Fe-Co-K and Fe-Mg-K catalysts also exhibited commendable stability, although with a slight gradual decline in the CO2 conversion observed over the 84-hour period. While these catalysts exhibited a minor degree of deactivation with time-on-steam, their overall stability remains significantly better than that of the unpromoted Fe-K catalyst. In contrast, the Fe-Cu-K and Fe-Mn-K catalysts displayed notably poor stability, with significant variations in CO2 conversion throughout the reaction time, indicating a potential change under continuous reaction conditions The above studies highlight the critical role of promoter selection in determining the long-term performance of iron-based catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. Zn promoter, in particular, effectively enhances catalytic stability, likely through its anti-sintering effect and stabilization of the active iron phase. Table S4 provides a comparative analysis of the catalytic performance of catalysts synthesized in this work against Fe-K catalysts reported in recent literature. Compared to catalysts prepared by co-precipitation method, Prussian blue analogue (PBA) precursor or citric acid combustion method [53–55], the catalysts synthesized using the activated carbon template method proposed in this work exhibits notably higher specific surface areas. This advantage is particularly evident when considering the impact of Mn promotion. While Dossary et al. [56] observed a decrease in specific surface area with the addition of Mn, our Mn-containing catalysts, prepared using the activated carbon template, showed an increase. This may be attributed to the effectiveness of activated carbon in promoting metal dispersion and high surface area. Moreover, compared to those synthesized via citric acid combustion method, the catalysts developed in this study demonstrates superior reducibility [55]. As Table S4 demonstrates, catalysts prepared in this work achieve higher CO2 conversion and light olefin selectivity at high GHSV under comparable reaction conditions, compared to reference catalysts. For example, the Co-modified Fe-K catalyst in this work outperforms the FeCoK catalyst reported by Jia et al. [57]. This improved performance is likely linked to the enhanced dispersion, surface area and reducibility imparted by the activated carbon template method. Notably, the Zn- and Mn-modified catalysts prepared via the citric acid combustion method exhibit relatively low CO2 conversion and high C5 + selectivity [55,58]. Guo et al. [59] reported that the incorporation of Co into catalysts can enhance CH4 selectivity and improves both the reduction and carburization behavior of the catalysts and our findings regarding Co promotion is also consistent with their results. It is noted that some catalysts in Table S4 achieve higher CO2 conversion and olefin selectivity, potentially due to more favorable reaction conditions (lower GHSV, higher temperature and pressure). 4 Conclusion A novel activated carbon template method for synthesizing high-performance Fe-K catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation was proposed in this study. The catalysts synthesized via this approach exhibit a remarkable combination of high CO2 conversion and light olefin selectivity, while simultaneously effectively suppressing the formation of undesired by-products such as CO and methane. Among various Fe-based catalysts, Fe-Zn-K stands out for its exceptional selectivity towards light olefins (35.00 %) and the highest C2-C4 olefin to paraffin ratio (6.3). The incorporation of Zn, facilitated by the activated carbon template, significantly enhances the dispersion of iron species, promoting active sites accessibility and preventing sintering. Furthermore, Zn promotes electron transfer to iron species, leading to the formation of electron-rich Fe5C2, which directly correlates with the superior light olefin selectivity and olefin-to-paraffin ratio observed for Fe-Zn-K. In contrast, Fe-Co-K displays the highest CO2 conversion (46.88 %) and the lowest CO selectivity (8.09 %). Co, while also promoting Fe5C2 formation, appears to primarily enhance H2 dissociation, boosting hydrogenation activity and driving CO consumption via the FTS pathway. The addition of Mn was observed to exhibit the highest selectivity to CO and the lowest increase in the selectivity to light olefins, which may be attributed to the strong interaction between Mn and iron species that reduces catalyst basicity and inhibits CO consumption via FTS reaction. Cu addition greatly enhances the reduction and carburization behavior of iron oxides, which is favorable for the formation of Fe5C2. However, the introduction of Cu weakens the adsorption of CO2, which leads to a decrease in CO2 conversion compared to Fe-K. Interestingly, Cu, Mn and Mg promoters commonly promote C-C coupling, leading to lower CH4 and higher C5 + selectivity. In short, the activated carbon template method developed in this study significantly not only enhances the surface area and dispersion of the catalysts, but also improves their reduction and carburization behavior. The comprehensive investigation of various metal promoters synthesized by this approach provides a deep understanding of their individual roles in modulating the physicochemical properties and catalytic performance of Fe-K catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation. These findings offer valuable insights for the rational design of advanced catalysts for sustainable light olefin production from CO2. Data availability Data will be made available on request. coredata.dc:description: Efficient CO2 utilization is crucial for mitigating environmental concerns. In this study, the promoting effect of transition metal (Zn, Cu, Co and Mn) and alkaline earth metal Mg on Fe-K catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to light olefins were investigated. A series of Fe-K catalysts with different metal modified were prepared using the activated carbon template method proposed in this work. This method greatly improves catalyst dispersion, enabling the synthesis of high-performance Fe-K catalysts. The promoter-dependent mechanisms governing catalyst performance and selectivity were revealed. Zn promotion significantly enhances Fe dispersion and electron transfer, resulting in electron-rich Fe5C2 and exceptional light olefin selectivity with a value of 35.00 %. Co maximizes CO2 conversion (46.88 %). However, Co promotes H2 dissociation, enhancing the formation of n-alkane products and reducing C2-C4 olefin-to-paraffin ratio. Adding Cu, while greatly enhancing the reduction and carburization behavior of iron oxides, significantly weakens the adsorption of CO2. The strong interaction between Mn and iron species leads to a complex reduction and carburization process of Fe-K catalyst and greatly reduces its basicity. The addition of Cu, Mg, and Mn greatly promote C-C coupling towards heavier hydrocarbons. These findings provide a comprehensive understanding of promoter roles and offer a rational strategy for designing advanced Fe-K catalysts for tailed CO2 hydrogenation product distributions.
